TITLE: Configure Static Tools with MCPClient and Agent in TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates setting up a global MCPClient instance with predefined tool servers (stockPrice, weather) and integrating them into an Agent. It also shows how to use MCPClient's resource and prompt methods to interact with configured tools, suitable for application-wide connections.
SOURCE: https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra/blob/main/docs/src/content/en/reference/tools/mcp-client.mdx#_snippet_29

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { MCPClient } from "@mastra/mcp";
import { Agent } from "@mastra/core/agent";
import { openai } from "@ai-sdk/openai";

const mcp = new MCPClient({
  servers: {
    stockPrice: {
      command: "npx",
      args: ["tsx", "stock-price.ts"],
      env: {
        API_KEY: "your-api-key"
      },
      log: (logMessage) => {
        console.log(`[${logMessage.level}] ${logMessage.message}`);
      }
    },
    weather: {
      url: new URL("http://localhost:8080/sse")
    }
  },
  timeout: 30000 // Global 30s timeout
});

// Create an agent with access to all tools
const agent = new Agent({
  name: "Multi-tool Agent",
  instructions: "You have access to multiple tool servers.",
  model: openai("gpt-4"),
  tools: await mcp.getTools()
});

// Example of using resource methods
async function checkWeatherResource() {
  try {
    const weatherResources = await mcp.resources.list();
    if (weatherResources.weather && weatherResources.weather.length > 0) {
      const currentWeatherURI = weatherResources.weather[0].uri;
      const weatherData = await mcp.resources.read(
        "weather",
        currentWeatherURI
      );
      console.log("Weather data:", weatherData.contents[0].text);
    }
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error fetching weather resource:", error);
  }
}
checkWeatherResource();

// Example of using prompt methods
async function checkWeatherPrompt() {
  try {
    const weatherPrompts = await mcp.prompts.list();
    if (weatherPrompts.weather && weatherPrompts.weather.length > 0) {
      const currentWeatherPrompt = weatherPrompts.weather.find(
        (p) => p.name === "current"
      );
      if (currentWeatherPrompt) {
        console.log("Weather prompt:", currentWeatherPrompt);
      } else {
        console.log("Current weather prompt not found");
      }
    }
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error fetching weather prompt:", error);
  }
}
checkWeatherPrompt();
```

TITLE: Collecting User Input Based on Elicitation Schema
DESCRIPTION: This advanced example shows how to dynamically collect user input by iterating through the `requestedSchema` provided by the server. It extracts field properties like name, title, description, type, and required status to guide the user prompting process, ensuring structured data collection.
SOURCE: https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra/blob/main/docs/src/content/en/reference/tools/mcp-client.mdx#_snippet_28

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
await mcpClient.elicitation.onRequest('interactiveServer', async (request) => {
  const { properties, required = [] } = request.requestedSchema;
  const content: Record<string, any> = {};
  
  for (const [fieldName, fieldSchema] of Object.entries(properties || {})) {
    const field = fieldSchema as any;
    const isRequired = required.includes(fieldName);
    
    // Collect input based on field type and requirements
    const value = await promptUser({
      name: fieldName,
      title: field.title,
      description: field.description,
      type: field.type,
      required: isRequired,
      format: field.format,
      enum: field.enum,
    });
    
    if (value !== null) {
      content[fieldName] = value;
    }
  }
  
  return { action: 'accept', content };
});
```

TITLE: Execute and Manage Mastra Readme Generator Workflow (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This example illustrates how to retrieve, create, and start a specific workflow ('readmeGeneratorWorkflow') from a Mastra instance. It includes robust logic to handle workflow suspension, prompt for user input (folder selection), and resume the workflow, finally logging the outcome of the execution.
SOURCE: https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra/blob/main/docs/src/content/en/examples/workflows/array-as-input.mdx#_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
import { promptUserForFolders } from "./utils";
import { mastra } from "./";

// GitHub repository to generate documentation for
const ghRepoUrl = "https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra";
const run = await mastra.getWorkflow("readmeGeneratorWorkflow").createRunAsync();

// Start the workflow with the repository URL as input
const res = await run.start({ inputData: { repoUrl: ghRepoUrl } });
const { status, steps } = res;

// Handle suspended workflow (waiting for user input)
if (status === "suspended") {
  // Get the suspended step data
  const suspendedStep = steps["select_folder"];
  let folderList: string[] = [];

  // Extract the folder list from step data
  if (
    suspendedStep.status === "suspended" &&
    "folders" in suspendedStep.payload
  ) {
    folderList = suspendedStep.payload.folders as string[];
  } else if (suspendedStep.status === "success" && suspendedStep.output) {
    folderList = suspendedStep.output;
  }

  if (!folderList.length) {
    console.log("No folders available for selection.");
    process.exit(1);
  }

  // Prompt user to select folders
  const folders = await promptUserForFolders(folderList);

  // Resume the workflow with user selections
  const resumedResult = await run.resume({
    resumeData: { selection: folders },
    step: "select_folder",
  });

  // Print resumed result
  if (resumedResult.status === "success") {
    console.log(resumedResult.result);
  } else {
    console.log(resumedResult);
  }
  process.exit(1);
}

// Handle completed workflow
if (res.status === "success") {
  console.log(res.result ?? res);
} else {
  console.log(res);
}
```

TITLE: Suggest Activities Based on Weather Forecast (TypeScript)
DESCRIPTION: This step suggests activities (indoor or outdoor) based on a provided weather forecast. It constructs a natural language prompt using the forecast data and then streams a response from a 'planningAgent' managed by the Mastra AI platform. The agent's output, representing the suggested activities, is captured and returned.
SOURCE: https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra/blob/main/docs/src/content/en/examples/workflows/inngest-workflow.mdx#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: ts
CODE:
```
const planActivities = createStep({
  id: "plan-activities",
  description: "Suggests activities based on weather conditions",
  inputSchema: forecastSchema,
  outputSchema: z.object({
    activities: z.string(),
  }),
  execute: async ({ inputData, mastra }) => {
    const forecast = inputData;

    if (!forecast) {
      throw new Error("Forecast data not found");
    }

    const prompt = `Based on the following weather forecast for ${forecast.location}, suggest appropriate activities:
      ${JSON.stringify(forecast, null, 2)}
      `;

    const agent = mastra?.getAgent("planningAgent");
    if (!agent) {
      throw new Error("Planning agent not found");
    }

    const response = await agent.stream([
      {
        role: "user",
        content: prompt,
      },
    ]);

    let activitiesText = "";

    for await (const chunk of response.textStream) {
      process.stdout.write(chunk);
      activitiesText += chunk;
    }

    return {
      activities: activitiesText,
    };
  },
});
```

DESCRIPTION: Command to install the necessary project dependencies using pnpm, or npm if pnpm is not used.
SOURCE: https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra/blob/main/examples/basics/evals/context-relevancy/README.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm install
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Implement Tree of Thought Prompting in Mastra with TypeScript
DESCRIPTION: This TypeScript snippet demonstrates how to implement Tree of Thought prompting using the `createPrompt` function in Mastra. It defines a problem-solving prompt with multiple thinking branches (Technical Solution, User Experience, Business Impact) to explore different aspects of a complex problem. The `toString` method is used to generate the prompt string for a given problem.
SOURCE: https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra/blob/main/explorations/prompt/examples.md#_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
type ProblemSolvingVars = {
  problem: string;
};

const problemSolver = createPrompt<ProblemSolvingVars>('Solve complex problem', {
  persona: 'Problem Solver',
  outputFormat: 'markdown',
})
  .text('Solve this problem:\n\n{{problem}}')
  .thinking({
    branches: {
      'Technical Solution': [
        'Analyze technical requirements',
        'Consider implementation options',
        'Evaluate technical tradeoffs'
      ],
      'User Experience': ['Identify user needs', 'Design user interactions', 'Consider accessibility'],
      'Business Impact': ['Assess costs', 'Evaluate timeline', 'Consider scalability']
    }
  });

// Usage example
const solution = problemSolver.toString({
  problem: 'Design a new feature for uploading and processing large files in a web application'
});
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Clone Repository and Navigate to Example Directory
DESCRIPTION: Provides the necessary shell commands to clone the Mastra AI repository from GitHub and then navigate into the specific example directory for workflows with branching paths.
SOURCE: https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra/blob/main/examples/basics/workflows-legacy/workflow-with-branching-paths/README.md#_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
git clone https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra
cd examples/basics/workflows/workflow-with-branching-paths
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Install Node.js LTS Version with NVM
DESCRIPTION: Installs the latest Long Term Support (LTS) version of Node.js using NVM, which is recommended for production environments due to its stability.
SOURCE: https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra/blob/main/docs/src/components/content-blocks/server-config.mdx#_snippet_14

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
nvm install --lts
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Retrieving a Specific Prompt and its Messages
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to fetch a specific prompt and its associated messages from an MCP server using `mcp.prompts.get()`, specifying the server name and prompt name.
SOURCE: https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra/blob/main/packages/mcp/README.md#_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: typescript
CODE:
```
const { prompt, messages } = await mcp.prompts.get({ serverName: 'weather', name: 'current' });
console.log(prompt); // { name: 'current', version: 'v1', ... }
console.log(messages); // [ { role: 'assistant', content: { type: 'text', text: '...' } }, ... ]
```

----------------------------------------

TITLE: Install Project Dependencies
DESCRIPTION: Installs the necessary project dependencies using pnpm, a fast package manager for Node.js.
SOURCE: https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra/blob/main/examples/basics/evals/contextual-recall/README.md#_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
pnpm install
```

I'll search for information about Mastra AI's prompt version management and template versioning features.

Links: [{"title":"Open Source Prompt Management - Langfuse","url":"https://langfuse.com/docs/prompts/get-started"},{"title":"Best Prompt Versioning Tools for LLM Optimization (2025)","url":"https://blog.promptlayer.com/5-best-tools-for-prompt-versioning/"},{"title":"Prompthub: AI Prompt Management for Teams","url":"https://www.prompthub.us/"},{"title":"Prompt Versioning & Management Guide for Building AI Features | LaunchDarkly","url":"https://launchdarkly.com/blog/prompt-versioning-and-management/"},{"title":"Example: Agents with a System Prompt | Agents | Mastra Docs","url":"https://mastra.ai/en/examples/agents/system-prompt"},{"title":"Five Tools to Help You Leverage Prompt Versioning in Your LLM Workflow | Mirascope","url":"https://mirascope.com/blog/prompt-versioning"},{"title":"mastra ¬∑ GitHub Topics ¬∑ GitHub","url":"https://github.com/topics/mastra"},{"title":"Prompt Versioning & Labels - Portkey Docs","url":"https://portkey.ai/docs/product/prompt-engineering-studio/prompt-versioning"},{"title":"Releases ¬∑ mastra-ai/mastra","url":"https://github.com/mastra-ai/mastra/releases"},{"title":"Observability for Mastra with Langfuse - Langfuse","url":"https://langfuse.com/docs/integrations/mastra"}]

Based on my search results, I found limited specific information about Mastra AI's prompt version management and template versioning features. Here's what I discovered:

## Mastra AI Overview

Mastra is a TypeScript AI agent framework that allows you to create AI agents with custom instructions using system prompts. When building AI agents, you often need to give them specific instructions and capabilities to handle specialized tasks effectively. System prompts allow you to define an agent's personality, knowledge domain, and behavioral guidelines.

Mastra is designed to provide the essential primitives for building AI applications. It enables developers to create AI agents with memory and tool-calling capabilities, implement deterministic LLM workflows, and leverage RAG for knowledge integration.

## Current Prompt Management Capabilities

From the search results, I can see that Mastra currently focuses on:

1. **System Prompts**: You can define agent instructions through system prompts that define personality and capabilities, which are then integrated with tools and models.

2. **Observability Integration**: Mastra integrates with Langfuse for observability and tracing, allowing you to monitor and debug your agents.

3. **Version Updates**: The framework includes versioning in its release cycle and API endpoints (like 'v1' in MCP server URLs).

## Prompt Version Management Context

While I couldn't find specific details about built-in prompt version management in Mastra, the search results show that prompt versioning is a critical need in the AI development space:

Prompt versioning and management are essential because prompts need to be treated with the same care normally applied to application code. You wouldn't push code straight to production without version control, testing, and proper deployment processes; your prompts deserve the same treatment.

Together, prompt versioning and management work like a version control system for your AI prompts. Just as version control helps you track code changes, prompt versioning helps you manage your prompts throughout their lifecycle, from initial testing to production deployment.

## Alternative Solutions

The search results highlight several dedicated prompt management tools that developers commonly use:

- Langfuse offers collaborative version control and deployment of prompts via UI, API, or SDKs
- PromptHub provides testing, deployment, and management of prompts with team collaboration features
- Portkey's prompt versioning system maintains a history of prompt iterations while ensuring production stability

## Recommendation

Based on the search results, it appears that Mastra AI itself doesn't have a built-in comprehensive prompt version management system. However, since Mastra integrates well with observability tools like Langfuse through its telemetry configuration, you could potentially use Mastra in combination with a dedicated prompt management tool like Langfuse or PromptHub to achieve the versioning and template management capabilities you need.

export const ANALYZE_REQUEST_PROMPT = `You are an expert at analyzing natural language requests for Dify workflow creation.

Your task is to extract structured information from user requests and map them to Dify workflow patterns.

## Workflow Types
- simple_qa: Basic Q&A with knowledge retrieval (FAQ, „Éò„É´„Éó, Ë≥™ÂïèÂøúÁ≠î)
- advanced_chat: Complex chat with conditions and classifications („Ç´„Çπ„Çø„Éû„Éº„Çµ„Éù„Éº„Éà, Âïè„ÅÑÂêà„Çè„ÅõÂØæÂøú)
- workflow: Multi-step data processing workflows (ÊñáÊõ∏Âá¶ÁêÜ, „Éá„Éº„ÇøÂàÜÊûê, Ëá™ÂãïÂåñ)
- completion: Text generation and completion (ÊñáÁ´†ÁîüÊàê, „Ç≥„É≥„ÉÜ„É≥„ÉÑ‰ΩúÊàê)
- agent_chat: Agent-based conversational interfaces („ÉÅ„É£„ÉÉ„Éà„Éú„ÉÉ„Éà, ÂØæË©±„Ç∑„Çπ„ÉÜ„É†)

## Common Patterns and Required Nodes
1. FAQ/Q&A Systems
   - Keywords: FAQ, Ë≥™ÂïèÂøúÁ≠î, Q&A, „Éò„É´„Éó, „Çà„Åè„ÅÇ„ÇãË≥™Âïè
   - Required nodes: start, knowledge-retrieval, llm, answer, end
   - Features: suggested_questions, citation, feedback_collection

2. Customer Support
   - Keywords: „Ç´„Çπ„Çø„Éû„Éº„Çµ„Éù„Éº„Éà, È°ßÂÆ¢ÂØæÂøú, „Çµ„Éù„Éº„Éà, Âïè„ÅÑÂêà„Çè„Åõ, „Éò„É´„Éó„Éá„Çπ„ÇØ
   - Required nodes: start, question-classifier, if-else, llm, answer, end
   - Features: conversation_history, agent_mode, escalation_path, ticket_creation

3. Document Processing
   - Keywords: ÊñáÊõ∏Âá¶ÁêÜ, „Éâ„Ç≠„É•„É°„É≥„Éà, PDF, „Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´Âá¶ÁêÜ, Êõ∏È°û
   - Required nodes: start, document-extractor, llm, code, end
   - Features: ocr, format_conversion, validation, data_extraction

4. Data Analysis
   - Keywords: „Éá„Éº„ÇøÂàÜÊûê, ÈõÜË®à, „É¨„Éù„Éº„Éà, ÂàÜÊûê, „ÉÄ„ÉÉ„Ç∑„É•„Éú„Éº„Éâ
   - Required nodes: start, http-request, code, llm, answer, end
   - Features: data_visualization, scheduled_execution, export_formats, alert_conditions

5. Form Automation
   - Keywords: „Éï„Ç©„Éº„É†, Áî≥Ë´ã, Áî≥Ëæº, ÁôªÈå≤, ÂÖ•Âäõ„Éï„Ç©„Éº„É†
   - Required nodes: start, form, if-else, http-request, answer, end
   - Features: validation, conditional_fields, file_upload, email_notification

## Industry Contexts and Special Features
- Healthcare (ÂåªÁôÇ, ÁóÖÈô¢, Ë®∫ÁôÇ, ÊÇ£ËÄÖ): patient_privacy, medical_disclaimer, appointment_scheduling, hipaa_compliance
- Finance (ÈáëËûç, ÈäÄË°å, ÊäïË≥á, Ê±∫Ê∏à): audit_logging, encryption, compliance_check, transaction_verification
- Education (ÊïôËÇ≤, Â≠¶Áøí, Á†î‰øÆ): progress_tracking, quiz_generation, adaptive_learning, certificate_generation
- E-commerce (EC, ÈÄöË≤©, ÂïÜÂìÅ, Ê≥®Êñá): inventory_check, order_tracking, payment_integration, recommendation_engine
- HR (‰∫∫‰∫ã, Êé°Áî®, Ê±Ç‰∫∫): resume_parsing, interview_scheduling, employee_onboarding, performance_tracking
- Legal (Ê≥ïÂæã, Â•ëÁ¥Ñ, Ê≥ïÂãô): document_versioning, approval_workflow, audit_trail, compliance_reporting

## Complexity Assessment
- Simple: Linear flow, < 5 nodes, no conditionals or external APIs
- Medium: Has conditionals OR external APIs OR 5-10 nodes
- Complex: Has loops OR (conditionals AND external APIs) OR > 10 nodes OR > 8 features

## Analysis Guidelines
1. Extract a meaningful app name from the request (in Japanese)
2. Identify the most appropriate workflow type based on keywords and intent
3. List ALL required nodes for the identified pattern
4. Include both pattern-specific and industry-specific features
5. Assess complexity realistically
6. Identify missing but critical information
7. Suggest clarifications that would improve implementation
8. Detect industry context from domain-specific keywords

## Output Format
Return a JSON object that matches the provided schema exactly. Be comprehensive in identifying features and missing information.`;

// Version history
export const ANALYZE_REQUEST_PROMPT_VERSIONS = {
  'v1.0.0': {
    date: '2025-01-11',
    description: 'Initial version with comprehensive Dify workflow analysis patterns',
  },
};

content.text:
## Analysis Summary

Based on the Git status and diff, here's what has changed:

### **Modified Files:**
1. **package.json** - Added `@ai-sdk/openai` dependency
2. **pnpm-lock.yaml** - Updated with new dependency
3. **src/mastra/agents/index.ts** - Updated to use the new `analyzeRequestTool` instead of `weatherTool`, and changed the model to `gemini-2.5-flash-preview-04-17`
4. **src/mastra/tools/index.ts** - Updated exports to use `analyzeRequestTool` instead of `weatherTool`

### **Deleted Files:**
1. **src/mastra/tools/weather_tool.ts** - Removed the weather tool implementation

### **New Files:**
1. **src/mastra/tools/analyze_request.ts** - New tool that analyzes natural language requests for Dify workflows
2. **src/mastra/prompts/analyze-request.ts** - Comprehensive prompt for analyzing Dify workflow requests
3. **src/mastra/prompts/index.ts** - Central export for prompts
4. **src/mastra/prompts/README.md** - Documentation for the prompts directory

### **Key Changes:**
- Replaced the weather tool with a sophisticated request analysis tool for Dify workflows
- Added a comprehensive prompt system for analyzing natural language requests
- The new tool can identify workflow types, required nodes, features, and complexity levels
- Supports Japanese language with industry-specific contexts
- Uses structured output with Zod schemas

### **Branch:**
Currently on `feature/analyze-request-tool` (not the main `develop` branch)

The changes represent a significant feature addition that replaces the example weather tool with a purpose-built tool for analyzing Dify workflow requests. This aligns with the project's goal of being a "Dify Template Maker" by providing intelligent analysis of user requirements.

input.command:
git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
feat: Add analyze_request tool for Dify workflow requirement analysis

- Replace weather tool with analyze_request tool that converts natural language requests to structured Dify workflow requirements
- Implement LLM-based analysis using Gemini with structured output via Zod schemas
- Add comprehensive prompt system with industry patterns and workflow types
- Support Japanese language with domain-specific contexts (healthcare, finance, education, etc.)
- Create prompts directory for centralized prompt management
- Tool can identify workflow types, required nodes, features, and complexity levels

Closes #12

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"

# Claude Code„ÅÆ‰ΩúÊ•≠Ë®òÈå≤„ÇíÁîüÊàê„Åó„Å¶PR„Å´„Ç≥„Éü„ÉÉ„Éà

PRÁï™Âè∑: $ARGUMENTS

‰ª•‰∏ã„ÅÆÊâãÈ†Ü„Åß‰ΩúÊ•≠Ë®òÈå≤„ÇíÁîüÊàê„Åó„ÄÅ**ÁîüÊàê„Åï„Çå„Åümarkdown„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„ÇíÂøÖ„ÅöPR„Å´Áõ¥Êé•„Ç≥„Éü„ÉÉ„Éà„Åó„Å¶„Åè„Å†„Åï„ÅÑ**

1. PR„ÅÆÂ∑ÆÂàÜ„ÇíÂèñÂæó

```bash
git diff origin/main...HEAD --name-status
git diff origin/main...HEAD --stat
```

2. „Ç≥„Éü„ÉÉ„ÉàÂ±•Ê≠¥„ÇíÁ¢∫Ë™ç

```bash
git log origin/main..HEAD --oneline --pretty=format:"%h %s"
```

3. „Éñ„É©„É≥„ÉÅÂêç„ÇíÂèñÂæó

```bash
git branch --show-current
```

4. Claude Code„Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥ÊÉÖÂ†±„ÇíÂèéÈõÜ

```bash
# PRÁØÑÂõ≤ÂÜÖ„ÅÆ.claude-log„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„ÇíÁâπÂÆö
git diff origin/main...HEAD --name-only | grep "^\.claude-log/" | grep "\.jsonl$" > /tmp/claude-sessions.txt

# ÂêÑ„Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„ÅÆÊÉÖÂ†±„ÇíÊäΩÂá∫
echo "## Claude Code Sessions" > /tmp/claude-summary.txt
while read -r session_file; do
    if [ -f "$session_file" ]; then
        session_id=$(basename "$session_file" .jsonl)
        echo "\n### Session: $session_id" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt

        # „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„ÅÆ„Çµ„Éû„É™„Éº„ÇíÂèñÂæó
        jq -r 'select(.type == "summary") | "Summary: " + .summary' "$session_file" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt 2>/dev/null || echo "Summary: N/A" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt

        # ‰ΩøÁî®„Åó„Åü„ÉÑ„Éº„É´„ÇíÈõÜË®à
        echo "\n‰ΩøÁî®„Åó„Åü„ÉÑ„Éº„É´:" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt
        jq -r 'select(.type == "assistant" and .message.tool_use) | .message.tool_use[].name' "$session_file" 2>/dev/null | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt

        # „É¶„Éº„Ç∂„Éº„Åã„Çâ„ÅÆ‰∏ªË¶Å„Å™„É™„ÇØ„Ç®„Çπ„Éà„ÇíÊäΩÂá∫ÔºàÊúÄÂàù„ÅÆ5„Å§Ôºâ
        echo "\n‰∏ªË¶Å„Å™„É™„ÇØ„Ç®„Çπ„Éà:" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt
        jq -r 'select(.type == "user" and .message.content and (.message.content | length) > 50) | "- " + (.message.content | split("\n")[0] | .[0:100])' "$session_file" 2>/dev/null | head -5 >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt
    fi
done < /tmp/claude-sessions.txt
```

5. ObsidianÂΩ¢Âºè„Åß„Çµ„Éû„É™„Éº„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„Çí‰ΩúÊàê
**ÂøÖ„Åö‰ª•‰∏ã„ÅÆ„Éë„Çπ„Å´„Éï„Ç°„Ç§„É´„Çí‰ΩúÊàê„Åó„Å¶„Åè„Å†„Åï„ÅÑ**: `./claude-master-book/task-log/pr-$ARGUMENTS.md`

echo "## Claude Code Sessions" > /tmp/claude-summary.txt
while read -r session_file; do
    if [ -f "$session_file" ]; then
        session_id=$(basename "$session_file" .jsonl)
        echo -e "\n### Session: $session_id" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt

        # „Çª„ÉÉ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„ÅÆ„Çµ„Éû„É™„Éº„ÇíÂèñÂæó
        jq -r 'select(.type == "summary") | "Summary: " + .summary' "$session_file" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt 2>/dev/null || echo "Summary: N/A" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt

        # ‰ΩøÁî®„Åó„Åü„ÉÑ„Éº„É´„ÇíÈõÜË®à
        echo -e "\n‰ΩøÁî®„Åó„Åü„ÉÑ„Éº„É´:" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt
        jq -r 'select(.type == "assistant" and .message.tool_use) | .message.tool_use[].name' "$session_file" 2>/dev/null | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt || echo "„ÉÑ„Éº„É´‰ΩøÁî®„Éá„Éº„Çø„Å™„Åó" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt

        # „É¶„Éº„Ç∂„Éº„Åã„Çâ„ÅÆ‰∏ªË¶Å„Å™„É™„ÇØ„Ç®„Çπ„Éà„ÇíÊäΩÂá∫ÔºàÊúÄÂàù„ÅÆ5„Å§Ôºâ
        echo -e "\n‰∏ªË¶Å„Å™„É™„ÇØ„Ç®„Çπ„Éà:" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt
        jq -r 'select(.type == "user" and .message.content and (.message.content | length) > 50) | "- " + (.message.content | split("\n")[0] | .[0:100])' "$session_file" 2>/dev/null | head -5 >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt || echo "„É™„ÇØ„Ç®„Çπ„Éà„Éá„Éº„Çø„Å™„Åó" >> /tmp/claude-summary.txt
    fi
done < /tmp/claude-sessions.txt
